reasoning: The critique targets a real, somewhat central component of the paper’s overall case—its claim in §3.3 that separately-aggregating bounded views tend to make “mostly-great” futures rare because even tiny fractions of bads can dominate. However, the critique largely hinges on a misreading: the paper does not argue that *any* nonzero bads automatically preclude mostly-great futures; it argues that, given their toy parameters (e.g., 10^22 stars and an assumed low-ish bound), a fraction like 1/10^22 bads could be enough to drop below 0.5 overall value. Also, the claim that thermodynamics “guarantees some suffering somewhere” is not established and is at best highly contestable (physical constraints imply waste heat/entropy production, not morally bad experiences). Still, the critique gestures at a legitimate failure mode: if a theory’s ‘tolerable bad’ threshold were below unavoidable minimums, the ‘mostly-great’ set could become empty, creating a vacuity problem—so it slightly weakens that subsection. It is clear and focused, with little fluff, but its key empirical/physical necessity premise and its attribution to the paper are not very correct.
title: Thermodynamic constraints make zero-bads thresholds physically impossible for any future
